questions.text: Dactylolysis Spontanea most commonly involves the? (NEET 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dactylolysis Spontanea, also known as Ainhum, is a condition characterized by a painful constriction at the base of the fifth toe. This constriction forms a fibrous band that progressively tightens around the digit, leading to necrosis and eventual spontaneous auto-amputation. This condition is most commonly seen in individuals who have a history of running barefoot during childhood. The pathogenesis includes the development of a fissure at the interphalangeal joint, which deepens over time and involves tendons, nerves, and blood vessels, eventually leading to bone separation without bleeding.
  • • Characteristics of Ainhum:
  • • Characteristics of Ainhum:
  • • Most commonly affects the base of the fifth toe Can occasionally affect other toes Common in males and individuals of African descent Often bilateral Progressive stages from grooving pain to auto-amputation
  • • Most commonly affects the base of the fifth toe
  • • Can occasionally affect other toes
  • • Common in males and individuals of African descent
  • • Often bilateral
  • • Progressive stages from grooving pain to auto-amputation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Base of great toe: Incorrect. Not commonly involved in Dactylolysis Spontanea.
  • • Option
  • • A. Base of great toe:
  • • Option B. Base of third toe: Incorrect. Not commonly involved in Dactylolysis Spontanea.
  • • Option
  • • B. Base of third toe:
  • • Option D. Base of fourth toe: Incorrect. Not commonly involved in Dactylolysis Spontanea.
  • • Option
  • • D. Base of fourth toe:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dactylolysis Spontanea most commonly affects the base of the fifth toe and can lead to spontaneous auto-amputation over a period of several years.

questions.text: A lady with history of smoking presents with nipple discharge. She is diagnosed with duct ectasia. What is the procedure to be done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hadfield procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hadfield procedure is used to excise multiple affected ducts in patients with duct ectasia.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? ( INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.correct_answer: A. Genetic counselling and screening for BRA
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: Match the following positions of the appendix: ( INICET MAY 2023) Subcaecal Retrocaecal Inside the pelvis Paracaecal
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage. Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.
  • ➤ Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • ➤ Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 2 cm in size can be treated with this form of treatment.
  • ➤ Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma.
  • ➤ Complications:
  • ➤ Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients on oral anticoagulants.
  • ➤ Note: Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the lesion shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Keloid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own. They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition. Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.
  • ➤ Keloids are raised scars that extend beyond the original wound margin, are progressive, and do not regress on their own.
  • ➤ They are most commonly seen in individuals with darker skin and may have a genetic predisposition.
  • ➤ Treatment involves silicon sheets, intralesional steroids, laser ablation, and sometimes surgical excision with radiotherapy.

questions.text: Identify which of these is not a component of qSOFA? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bilateral absent pupillary reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ qSOFA includes three criteria for assessing sepsis risk: respiratory rate ≥ 22/min, systolic BP < 100 mm Hg, and altered mental status. It does not include pupillary reflex assessment.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Renal calculus of > 4 cm of the Staghorn type. What is the best management modality in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the gold standard for the management of large and complex stones, like in this case.
  • ➤ PCNL is indicated in
  • ➤ Staghorn calculi - Stone >2 cm Multiple stones - >1 cm
  • ➤ Staghorn calculi - Stone >2 cm
  • ➤ Multiple stones - >1 cm
  • ➤ ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially when there has been insufficient disintegration.
  • ➤ Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:
  • ➤ Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:
  • ➤ Hemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track
  • ➤ Hemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • ➤ Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • ➤ Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated based on eye response, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score indicating the level of consciousness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES. Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention. The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic). Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.
  • ➤ Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • ➤ Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • ➤ Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson is a 60-year-old woman who underwent a Whipple's procedure for pancreatic cancer three weeks ago. She developed a fever and abdominal pain, and her surgeon suspected a postoperative complication. Which of the following complications causes maximum malnutrition? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duodenal fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A duodenal fistula (option B) is the postoperative complication that can cause maximum malnutrition due to its disruption of nutrient absorption in the critical site of the digestive process, the duodenum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed. What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.
  • ➤ Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

questions.text: A thirty-year-old male presents to the Emergency Department with symptoms of epigastric pain radiating to the back that wakes him up at night and is relieved by consuming food. He gives a history of similar pain in the past which was diagnosed as a perforated duodenal ulcer and treated with omental patch surgery on two occasions. Pain before and after surgery has been controlled with proton pump inhibitors and analgesics. The likely diagnosis on this occasion is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Duodenal Ulcer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's presentation of epigastric pain radiating to the back that is relieved by food and awakens him at night is characteristic of a duodenal ulcer. This type of pain occurs when the stomach is empty, typically during the night, and is relieved by food, which buffers the stomach acid. This symptom pattern, along with the patient's history of a previously diagnosed and surgically treated duodenal ulcer, strongly suggests a recurrence of the duodenal ulcer.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Gastric Ulcer: Incorrect. Pain from gastric ulcers is typically exacerbated by food and does not usually wake the patient at night.
  • • Option B. Gastric Ulcer:
  • • Option C. Atrophic Gastritis: Incorrect. Atrophic gastritis generally presents with chronic dyspepsia and may not cause severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.
  • • Option C. Atrophic Gastritis:
  • • Option D. Chronic Pancreatitis: Incorrect. Pancreatic pain is not typically relieved by food; it is often exacerbated by eating and relieved by leaning forward.
  • • Option D. Chronic Pancreatitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epigastric pain that radiates to the back, awakens the patient at night, and is relieved by food is highly suggestive of a duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, following binge drinking and heavy meals, was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumomediastinum was present. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophageal perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome) can occur after episodes of forceful vomiting or retching, especially following binge drinking and heavy meals. It presents with severe chest pain and pneumomediastinum and requires prompt surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.
  • ➤ Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.

options.label: C
options.text: Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

options.label: D
options.text: Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.correct_answer: C. Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus. This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
  • ➤ During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • ➤ This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: A man who had undergone cholecystectomy presented five days after the surgery with abdominal pain and tachycardia. WBC count is 13000 cells/mm3. US showed fluid collection 7x7 cm in right sub-hepatic space. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: US guided pig tail catheter drainage

questions.correct_answer: B. US guided pig tail catheter drainage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) US guided pig tail catheter drainage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Management of acute bile duct injury:
  • ➤ S- Sepsis control by pigtail catheter or surgical drainage
  • ➤ S- Sepsis control by pigtail catheter or surgical drainage
  • ➤ N- Nutrition
  • ➤ N- Nutrition
  • ➤ A- Anatomical delineation via MRCP/ERCP
  • ➤ A- Anatomical delineation via MRCP/ERCP
  • ➤ P- Planned reconstruction
  • ➤ P- Planned reconstruction

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamo-columnar junction located proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sliding hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sliding hernia is the condition most likely responsible for the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy, indicating the upward movement of the stomach through the hiatal opening.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.
  • ➤ Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)
  • ➤ C - Chest wall invasion
  • ➤ U - Ulceration of skin
  • ➤ B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)
  • ➤ E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma
  • ➤ N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following office-based procedures for internal hemorrhoids has the least recurrence rates:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rubber band ligation (RBL)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Among the various office-based procedures for treating internal hemorrhoids, rubber band ligation (RBL) is considered to have the lowest recurrence rates and the need for retreatment. RBL works by placing a rubber band around the base of the hemorrhoid, cutting off its blood supply, causing it to wither and fall off. This procedure is effective for grade I, II, and some grade III hemorrhoids and has the advantage of removing redundant tissue with minimal discomfort.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Injection sclerotherapy : Higher recurrence rates compared to RBL.
  • • Option A. Injection sclerotherapy
  • • Option C. Photocoagulation : Higher recurrence rates and more expensive than RBL.
  • • Option C. Photocoagulation
  • • Option D. Electrocoagulation : Higher recurrence rates and more complications compared to RBL.
  • • Option D. Electrocoagulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubber band ligation (RBL) has the lowest recurrence rates among office-based procedures for internal hemorrhoids.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female is admitted to the hospital with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. A nasogastric (NG) tube is inserted to decompress the stomach. However, the patient remains conscious and alert during the procedure. What is the best position to place the patient in during the insertion of the NG tube? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.
  • ➤ Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:
  • ➤ Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air Aspiration of gastric contents X-ray chest + upper abdomen
  • ➤ Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • ➤ Aspiration of gastric contents
  • ➤ X-ray chest + upper abdomen
  • ➤ The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach
  • ➤ 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum
  • ➤ 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  • ➤ 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  • ➤ 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  • ➤ 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum
  • ➤ The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:
  • ➤ Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:
  • ➤ Thyroid swellings Subhyoid bursitis Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone
  • ➤ Thyroid swellings
  • ➤ Subhyoid bursitis
  • ➤ Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone
  • ➤ However, amongst these only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This occurs because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland.
  • ➤ Sistrunk's operation is the procedure performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, along with removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.correct_answer: B. Foreign body in the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged. Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view. Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.
  • ➤ In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • ➤ Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  • ➤ Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Achalasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic triad of dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient , along with imaging showing smooth narrowing and gradual tapering, is highly suggestive of achalasia .
  • ➤ dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient
  • ➤ achalasia

questions.text: Split skin graft is composed of? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epidermis & partial dermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A split-thickness skin graft includes both the epidermis and part of the dermis, commonly harvested from the thigh.
  • ➤ Humby’s Knife (for harvesting partial thickness graft)

questions.text: During a surgical procedure on a patient exhibiting symptoms indicative of peritonitis, a diverticular rupture is observed, accompanied by fecal peritonitis. What would be the corresponding stage according to the Hinchey's classification? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stage 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hinchey's Classification of diverticulitis is essential for determining the appropriate management strategy. Stage IV in Hinchey's classification corresponds to fecal peritonitis, which requires immediate surgical intervention, typically Hartmann's surgery.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? ( NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

options.label: B
options.text: Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle

options.label: D
options.text: Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.correct_answer: A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.
  • • Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle:
  • • Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.
  • • Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle:
  • • Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.
  • • Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle:
  • • Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:
  • • Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:
  • • Origin : Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft. Lining : Squamous epithelium. Contents : Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny. Branchial Fistula : The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • • Origin : Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • • Origin
  • • Lining : Squamous epithelium.
  • • Lining
  • • Contents : Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • • Contents
  • • Branchial Fistula : The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • • Branchial Fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cecum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.
  • ➤ Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.
  • ➤ Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contaminated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection
  • ➤ Contaminated

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Resection and anastomosis

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing at home. Suddenly his mother found him lying on the floor choking. She suspects he has ingested a foreign body and rushes him to the casualty. An X-ray is done which shows the following picture. What is the next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediate Endoscopic removal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a foreign body such as a coin is detected in the esophagus on X-ray, immediate endoscopic removal is indicated to prevent potential complications.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with dysphagia to solids, weight loss and regurgitation. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ca Esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly smoker presenting with dysphagia to solids, weight loss, and regurgitation, Ca esophagus should be considered as the probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels. This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.
  • ➤ Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • ➤ This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a breast condition as demonstrated in the image below. This condition is due to invasion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dermal lymphatics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The peau d'orange appearance of the breast is due to blockage of the superficial dermal lymphatics by tumor invasion, leading to edema and the characteristic skin changes.

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)

Ans. A) Nylon

questions.text: You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021) Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour. Colon cancer can have hereditary components. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer. Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

questions.text: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope. ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree. Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry. Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures. ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.
  • ➤ ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, which is used to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree using a side-viewing endoscope.
  • ➤ ERCP can be therapeutic or diagnostic and is the best modality for examining the distal biliary tree.
  • ➤ Indications for ERCP include relieving biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease, biliary drainage, biliary stenting for strictures and leakage, tissue sampling of the biliary or pancreatic ductal system, balloon dilation of the duodenal papilla or ductal strictures, sphincterotomy, and sphincter of Oddi manometry.
  • ➤ Therapeutic ERCP is most commonly used to alleviate biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.
  • ➤ ERCP can be used to diagnose pancreatic divisum, which may present with recurrent pancreatitis.

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement

options.label: D
options.text: To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.correct_answer: D. To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery. If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes. Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided. In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.
  • ➤ The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • ➤ If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • ➤ Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • ➤ In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: A lady presented with burns from the neck to the lower back. Preferred sequence of treatment in this Lady? (FMGE JUNE 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: First debridement then reconstruction and then resuscitation

options.label: C
options.text: First resuscitation then reconstruction and then debridement

options.label: D
options.text: First resuscitation, then debridement and then autograft + allograft

questions.correct_answer: D. First resuscitation, then debridement and then autograft + allograft
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) First resuscitation, then debridement and then autograft + allograft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of severe burns, the primary priority is resuscitation to prevent hypovolemic shock, followed by debridement, and then grafting the burned skin with autograft or allograft.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Cervical branch of facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

questions.text: For a rectal carcinoma at 5 cm from the anal verge, the best acceptable operation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Abdominal perineal resection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A rectal carcinoma located 5 cm from the anal verge is in the lower rectum. The appropriate surgical procedure for treating distal rectal cancer is Abdominal perineal resection (APR). This procedure involves the complete excision of the rectum and anus through simultaneous abdominal and perineal approaches. The significant disadvantage of APR is the loss of the sphincter mechanism, necessitating a permanent colostomy. However, it remains the gold standard for cancers in this location due to its thoroughness in removing the tumor and surrounding tissues.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anterior resection : Suitable for tumors in the upper rectum.
  • • Option A. Anterior resection
  • • Option C. Low anterior resection : Suitable for tumors in the mid rectum.
  • • Option C. Low anterior resection
  • • Option D. Local resection : Typically reserved for very early-stage tumors, not appropriate for lower rectal carcinomas at 5 cm.
  • • Option D. Local resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For rectal carcinoma located 5 cm from the anal verge, abdominal perineal resection (APR) is the gold standard surgical treatment.

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least side effects with good healing of ulcers? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is the preferred surgical option for chronic duodenal ulcers due to its effective reduction of acid secretion, minimal side effects, and good ulcer healing rate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence. The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.
  • • Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery:
  • • Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.
  • • Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency:
  • • Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.
  • • Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.
  • ➤ A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

questions.text: A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario? ( INICET MAY 2023) Brodie Trendelenburg Test Morrissey's test Fegan's test Modified Perthes test
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 2

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan

options.label: B
options.text: All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

options.label: C
options.text: X-ray of the pelvis is done in primary survey

options.label: D
options.text: X-rays in primary survey may also be done in pregnant women

questions.correct_answer: B. All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:
  • ➤ The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:
  • ➤ Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan
  • ➤ Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • ➤ Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries
  • ➤ Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan
  • ➤ ABCDE of trauma care:
  • ➤ ABCDE of trauma care:
  • ➤ Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation) Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion) Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation) Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)
  • ➤ Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • ➤ Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • ➤ Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • ➤ Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • ➤ Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)
  • ➤ Adjuncts to the primary survey are-
  • ➤ Adjuncts to the primary survey are-
  • ➤ Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids Urinary and gastric catheterization Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.
  • ➤ Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ➤ ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • ➤ Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • ➤ Urinary and gastric catheterization
  • ➤ Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.
  • ➤ Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA that caused crush injury. Within 3 days of the injury and post-amputation, crepitus was present and the wound was reddish brown. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gas gangrene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gas gangrene, characterized by rapid tissue destruction, gas production, and a reddish-brown appearance of the wound, should be promptly recognized and managed due to its potential for rapid progression and systemic complications.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female is undergoing thyroidectomy for a large goiter. During the procedure, the patient develops tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia. She becomes agitated and confused. Laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid hormone levels, and a diagnosis of thyroid storm is made. The surgical team immediately stops the procedure, and the patient is transferred to the intensive care unit for treatment. What is the most common cause of thyroid storm during thyroidectomy? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.
  • ➤ Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:
  • ➤ High fever Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia) Elevated blood pressure Extreme agitation and restlessness Profuse sweating Tremors and shaking Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea Delirium or confusion Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ High fever
  • ➤ Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  • ➤ Elevated blood pressure
  • ➤ Extreme agitation and restlessness
  • ➤ Profuse sweating
  • ➤ Tremors and shaking
  • ➤ Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • ➤ Delirium or confusion
  • ➤ Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • ➤ Coma (in severe cases)
  • ➤ Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.
  • ➤ Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.
  • ➤ The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively

options.label: B
options.text: Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored

options.label: C
options.text: Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

options.label: D
options.text: Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.correct_answer: C. Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.
  • ➤ Basal Cell Carcinoma

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Cysto-Urethroscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The insertion of a double J stent in the ureter is performed using a cysto-urethroscope, which allows for direct visualization of the bladder and ureteric orifices, enabling accurate stent placement.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about superior mesenteric artery syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Third part of duodenum is compressed

options.label: B
options.text: Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

questions.correct_answer: B. Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Angle between MA and aorta is more than 70 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SMA syndrome, also called Wilkie's syndrome, is characterized by an obstruction of the third part of the duodenum by the SMA due to compression against fixed retroperitoneal structures. Symptoms include episodic epigastric pain associated with vomiting.
  • ➤ SMA syndrome is associated with:
  • ➤ SMA syndrome is associated with:
  • ➤ Rapid growth during childhood Profound weight loss Abdominal surgery Inflammatory diseases of the GIT Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta
  • ➤ Rapid growth during childhood
  • ➤ Profound weight loss
  • ➤ Abdominal surgery
  • ➤ Inflammatory diseases of the GIT
  • ➤ Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta
  • ➤ Abdominal CT angiography is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ Treatment involves measures to promote weight gain like NJ feeds, which will lead to widening to aortomesenteric angle (due to deposition of fat). If it fails, then a duodeno-jejunal bypass is done.

questions.text: A condition requires the surgery depicted in the image shown below. Which of the following is not usually seen associated with this condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Absent kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image is of Porto-enterostomy procedure which is done for extra-hepatic biliary atresia. Associated anomalies occur in about 20% of cases and include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.
  • ➤ Portoenterostomy, also known as the Kasai procedure, is a surgical treatment for a condition called biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a rare and serious liver disease that affects neonates. In this condition, the bile ducts (intra/extrahepatic) are obliterated at birth.
  • ➤ The Portoenterostomy procedure involves the surgical creation of a new pathway for bile to flow from the liver into the small intestine. This is done by connecting a loop of the jejunum directly to the liver, allowing bile to bypass the blocked or absent bile ducts. The goal of the procedure is to restore bile flow and prevent liver damage, as untreated biliary atresia can lead to liver failure. Ideal management of high grades of biliary atresia (Kasai type 3) is liver transplant.
